purpose: Analyzes marital debt division under Pennsylvania law, tailored to Stephen Boerner’s bridge loan and preservation efforts in Delaware County divorce proceedings

client.name: Stephen Boerner
client.status: Disabled (PTSD/ADHD since 3/26/24), no income, pending SSDI, uninsured since 8/1/24
client.contributions: $53,900 total ($12k HVAC, $8.4k rental shortfall, $21k post-vacancy, $12.5k bridge loan)
client.debt: $12,500 bridge loan (1/3/25) for marital property preservation

opposingParty.name: Melissa A. Bemer
opposingParty.status: Full-time nurse since 12/1/24, insured, employment concealed
issues: Account closure ($3,790.35), self-payment ($1,500), Venmo cash-out ($4,500), insurance termination

property.status: Listed at $399,000 (3/15/25), unsold 230+ days, foreclosure risk post-4/16/25

definition.summary: Marital debt in Pennsylvania is defined analogously to marital property under 23 Pa.C.S. § 3501, encompassing debts incurred during marriage and before separation, subject to equitable distribution under 23 Pa.C.S. § 3502. Post-separation debts may be marital if they preserve joint assets.
definition.application: Stephen’s $12,500 bridge loan (1/3/25), though post-separation (10/1/24), is likely marital debt as it preserved the condo from foreclosure, benefiting both parties.

keyIssues.summary: Courts decide whether debt is assigned to one party or shared, considering contributions and dissipation under 23 Pa.C.S. § 3502(a)(7).
keyIssues.application: Melissa’s financial abandonment (zero contributions since 9/24) and misconduct (account closure, non-disclosure) justify assigning a significant portion of the bridge loan debt to her. Stephen’s sole payment of $53,900 supports shared or full allocation to Melissa.

legalAuthorities.holding: Full credit for marital debt payments from marital funds

keyIssues.summary: Courts may offset asset distribution for a party paying marital debt, with discretion based on fairness.
keyIssues.application: Stephen seeks credits for $12,500 bridge loan, $12,000 HVAC, and $29,400 carrying costs. His disability and Melissa’s abandonment support a minimum 75% credit to prevent her unjust enrichment.

legalAuthorities.holding: No credit due to equitable considerations

debtTypes.summary: Marital but often assigned to the educated spouse without offset, as the benefit is individual.

case.holding: Student loan assigned to educated spouse

debtTypes.application: Inapplicable; bridge loan benefits both parties by preserving joint property.

debtTypes.summary: Assigned to the incurring spouse without offset if due to misconduct.

case.holding: $10,000 fraud debt assigned solely to incurring spouse

debtTypes.application: Melissa’s account closure and non-disclosure could be analogized to misconduct, justifying greater debt assignment.

debtTypes.summary: Post-separation debts to preserve marital assets are often credited or shared.
debtTypes.application: Stephen’s bridge loan preserved condo equity, supporting its classification as marital debt with credits.

strategicConsiderations.details: Argue $12,500 loan is marital due to preservation purpose, supported by Hicks v. Kubit and Patwardhan v. Brabant (439 A.2d 784, Pa. Super. 1982). Seek shared responsibility or full credit.
Request minimum 75% credit for $53,900 contributions ($12k HVAC, $29.4k carrying costs, $12.5k bridge loan), citing Biese v. Biese and Robert v. Martin.
Melissa’s non-contribution and misconduct (account closure, non-disclosure) constitute dissipation under 23 Pa.C.S. § 3502(a)(7). Use Porter v. Porter (593 A.2d 376, Pa. 1991) for sanctions.
Stephen’s PTSD/ADHD and no income create dual vulnerability (Drumheller v. Drumheller, 972 A.2d 176, Pa. Super. 2009), supporting APL and credits.
Melissa’s FMLA rejection is actionable misconduct under Larkin v. Larkin (750 A.2d 895, Pa. Super. 2000), enhancing equitable relief claims.
Imminent default (4/16/25) invokes 23 Pa.C.S. § 3505 for emergency motions, supported by Horning v. Horning (600 A.2d 958, Pa. Super. 1991).

delawareCountyPerspective.summary: Delaware County courts prioritize economic justice, disability protections, and transparency, favoring credits for preservation and sanctions for misconduct.
tendencies: Retroactive contribution orders for disproportionate expenses (Johnston, Delaware Co. 2019-005672)
Emergency orders to prevent foreclosure (23 Pa.C.S. § 3323(f))
Credits for preservation efforts (Biese v. Biese, Robert v. Martin)
delawareCountyPerspective.application: Stephen’s disability, Melissa’s abandonment, and foreclosure risk strongly favor credits, emergency relief, and sanctions.

recommendations.details: By 4/18/25, file for foreclosure prevention and interim expense allocation, citing 23 Pa.C.S. § 3323(f) and Horning v. Horning.
Request 75% credit for $53,900 contributions, citing Biese v. Biese and Robert v. Martin.
Seek attorney’s fees for Melissa’s non-disclosure, citing Pa.R.C.P. 1920.33.
Request retroactive support from 12/1/24, citing 23 Pa.C.S. § 3702 and dual vulnerability.
Compile financial contribution table, medical records, and communication logs per Delaware Co. Local Rule 1920.51.
Keep $399k listing, reduce to $375k if no offers by 4/26/25, citing 23 Pa.C.S. § 3505.

conclusion.summary: Pennsylvania’s equitable distribution prioritizes fairness, supporting Stephen’s bridge loan as marital debt and justifying credits for his $53,900 contributions. Melissa’s abandonment and misconduct warrant sanctions and unequal distribution. Delaware County’s focus on disability and transparency favors Stephen’s claims for emergency relief and financial protection.
conclusion.strategicImpact: Immediate action is critical to prevent foreclosure, secure credits, and ensure economic justice.
